text: I'm testing an in-play strategy and in backtesting I am often getting matched at much better prices than I post due to BPE and the 1 second delay (I imagine). Has anyone found flumine's matching to be more generous than the odds matched when using real money? These favourable prices are contributing massively to the profitability of the strategy in backtesting

text:
Just to check, to avoid the scenario you describe you want BPE off not on.

BPE will ensure a price match if the odds are longer than your price (when backing), so in your scenario if you are trying to back @ 1.01 (presumably right at the end) and the odds lengthen, with BPE on you will get matched if the market is 7.6/7.8 (or whatever), with BPE off the order will get cancelled.

elements.text:
Just to check, to avoid the scenario you describe you want BPE off not on.

BPE will ensure a price match if the odds are longer than your price (when backing), so in your scenario if you are trying to back @ 1.01 (presumably right at the end) and the odds lengthen, with BPE on you will get matched if the market is 7.6/7.8 (or whatever), with BPE off the order will get cancelled.

text: (the reverse of course is also true, i.e. when laying)

elements.text: (the reverse of course is also true, i.e. when laying)

text: Yes BPE is on and in backtesting these matches are actually favourable and seem to have positive EV. So I want BPE to be on. I'm just hoping that the real matching is the same as in simulation. If so, the strategy must be placing bets at times of extreme volatility in order to get these kind of results.

elements.text: Yes BPE is on and in backtesting these matches are actually favourable and seem to have positive EV. So I want BPE to be on. text: Hi again, I've attached a comparison of one hour of real vs. simulated matched bets. In simulation, more bets are matched and it seems to display a higher average price matched much more frequently. With real money, it rarely matches at better odds than what is requested. Also in simulation there is one occasion where simulated average matched price is actually less than the asking price even though it is a back, which I didn't think could happen?

text:
Yeah so you have a lot of orders all going in at the same time, we can’t really simulate that sort of behaviour accurately.

What you are probably seeing is flumine continually matching against the same liquidity causing more orders to get fired in and then get ‘matched’ when in reality this won’t happen especially Inplay

elements.text: Yeah so you have a lot of orders all going in at the same time, we can’t really simulate that sort of behaviour accurately.
What you are probably seeing is flumine continually matching against the same liquidity causing more orders to get fired in and then get ‘matched’ when in reality this won’t happen especially Inplay
